liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A drone has hit a school in the southern Israeli city of Eilat, causing light damage, Israel's military said after Yemen's Houthi movement said it fired ballistic missiles toward the Red Sea port city. The Houthi's military spokesperson said they had launched "a barrage of ballistic missiles" at southern Israel, but did not mention drones in their statement. No-one was physically hurt in the explosion at the Eilat elementary school caused by the unidentified drone, but paramedics were treating seven people for shock, said an army spokeswoman at the scene. Emergency services confirmed the details separately. Residents clustered around the school complex, which was cordoned off by dozens of soldiers and police officers, an AFP reporter witnessed. Later on Thursday, the military said its Arrow air defence system intercepted a missile launched at Israeli territory near the Red Sea, and that its Patriot defence system had intercepted a "suspicious target" in the southern Negev desert. The Houthis said they launched a batch of ballistic missiles at various Israeli targets including what the group's military spokesperson described as military targets in Eilat. Houthi military spokesman Yahya Saree claimed "direct hits" after targeting "various sensitive targets of the Israeli entity … including military targets in the area of Umm al-Rashrash", the Arabic name of the town that stood where Eilat now is. Israel's military did not attribute blame for the missile launch or the target intercepted in the Negev. Israeli military spokesman Daniel Hagari told reporters the army was monitoring threats in the region, including against Eilat on the Red Sea coast. The Houthis have launched repeated missile and drone attacks on Israel since October 7 but all were either shot down or fell short. Reuters/AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says school hit in southern city of Eilat, Houthis say they fired missiles from Yemen

children.content: A drone has hit a school in the southern Israeli city of Eilat, causing light damage, Israel's military said after Yemen's Houthi movement said it fired ballistic missiles toward the Red Sea port city.
The Houthi's military spokesperson said they had launched "a barrage of ballistic missiles" at southern Israel, but did not mention drones in their statement.

No-one was physically hurt in the explosion at the Eilat elementary school caused by the unidentified drone, but paramedics were treating seven people for shock, said an army spokeswoman at the scene.
Emergency services confirmed the details separately.
Residents clustered around the school complex, which was cordoned off by dozens of soldiers and police officers, an AFP reporter witnessed.

Later on Thursday, the military said its Arrow air defence system intercepted a missile launched at Israeli territory near the Red Sea, and that its Patriot defence system had intercepted a "suspicious target" in the southern Negev desert.
The Houthis said they launched a batch of ballistic missiles at various Israeli targets including what the group's military spokesperson described as military targets in Eilat.

props.alt: a man wearing a militarty uniform stands at a podium

children.content: Yemen's Houthi military spokesperson
(Houthi Military Media via Reuters)

Houthi military spokesman Yahya Saree claimed "direct hits" after targeting "various sensitive targets of the Israeli entity … including military targets in the area of Umm al-Rashrash", the Arabic name of the town that stood where Eilat now is.
Israel's military did not attribute blame for the missile launch or the target intercepted in the Negev.
Israeli military spokesman Daniel Hagari told reporters the army was monitoring threats in the region, including against Eilat on the Red Sea coast.
The Houthis have launched repeated missile and drone attacks on Israel since October 7 but all were either shot down or fell short.
Reuters/AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel has agreed to pause military operations in parts of north Gaza for four hours a day from Thursday (local time), the White House said. The pauses, which would allow people to flee along two humanitarian corridors and could be used for the release of hostages, were significant first steps, White House national security spokesperson John Kirby said. But as night approached, there were no immediate reports of a lull in fighting raging among the ruined buildings in the north of the Gaza Strip. There was also no direct confirmation from Israel, which spoke more generally of measures that appeared to correspond to arrangements already in place. "We are undertaking localised and pinpoint measures to enable the exit of Palestinian civilians from Gaza City southward, so that we do not harm them. These things do not detract from the war fighting," Israeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said. However, he reiterated there would be no full ceasefire for now. "We will not stop fighting as long as our hostages are in Gaza and as long as we have not completed our mission, which is toppling the Hamas regime and eliminating its military and governance capabilities," he said. Israeli forces completely encircled Gaza City in recent days and the military has been allowing civilians safe passage along the main route south for three or four hours each day, with ever-growing numbers of families opting to escape. Former Middle East correspondent Eric Tlozek filed this report from Jerusalem:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US says Israel has agreed to four-hour-a-day 'humanitarian' pauses

children.content: Israel has agreed to pause military operations in parts of north Gaza for four hours a day from Thursday (local time), the White House said.

The pauses, which would allow people to flee along two humanitarian corridors and could be used for the release of hostages, were significant first steps, White House national security spokesperson John Kirby said.
But as night approached, there were no immediate reports of a lull in fighting raging among the ruined buildings in the north of the Gaza Strip.
There was also no direct confirmation from Israel, which spoke more generally of measures that appeared to correspond to arrangements already in place.

"We are undertaking localised and pinpoint measures to enable the exit of Palestinian civilians from Gaza City southward, so that we do not harm them. These things do not detract from the war fighting," Israeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said.
However, he reiterated there would be no full ceasefire for now.

"We will not stop fighting as long as our hostages are in Gaza and as long as we have not completed our mission, which is toppling the Hamas regime and eliminating its military and governance capabilities," he said.

Israeli forces completely encircled Gaza City in recent days and the military has been allowing civilians safe passage along the main route south for three or four hours each day, with ever-growing numbers of families opting to escape.
Former Middle East correspondent Eric Tlozek filed this report from Jerusalem:

mediaThumbnail.caption: The Israeli military has committed to holding no military operations in designated areas over the duration of the pauses.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Evacuations from the Gaza Strip into Egypt for foreign passport holders and Palestinians needing medical treatment have resumed through the Rafah crossing after being suspended for a day. Two Egyptian security and medical sources said 695 foreign passport holders and dependents, including Egyptians, were able to cross. Twelve Palestinian medical evacuees and 10 companions also entered Egypt, they added. Departures from Rafah had been paused on Wednesday due to what the US State Department referred to as an unspecified security issue. Three sources also said about 100 trucks of humanitarian aid had entered Gaza. The day before, 106 entered, bringing the total number since October 21 to 756, according to the UN. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Evacuations to Egypt resume for foreigners and Palestinian medical evacuees

children.content: Evacuations from the Gaza Strip into Egypt for foreign passport holders and Palestinians needing medical treatment have resumed through the Rafah crossing after being suspended for a day.
Two Egyptian security and medical sources said 695 foreign passport holders and dependents, including Egyptians, were able to cross.
Twelve Palestinian medical evacuees and 10 companions also entered Egypt, they added.
Departures from Rafah had been paused on Wednesday due to what the US State Department referred to as an unspecified security issue.
Three sources also said about 100 trucks of humanitarian aid had entered Gaza.
The day before, 106 entered, bringing the total number since October 21 to 756, according to the UN.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Before markets open here, let's wrap up how Wall Street finished. US stocks closed lower on Thursday (their time), snapping the longest winning streaks the S & P 500 and Nasdaq have had in two years. The drop came after Treasury yields climbed as a disappointing auction of 30-year bonds, and Fed boss Jerome Powell's "not confident" comments over interest rates. The Dow fell by 0.7% to 33,891 points, the S & P 500 lost 0.8% to 4,3747 points, and the Nasdaq lost 0.9% to 13.531. The falls are the biggest one-day percentage drops for both the S & P and Nasdaq since October 26, and the largest for the Dow since October 27.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: S&P 500, Nasdaq snap longest winning streak in two years

children.content: Before markets open here, let's wrap up how Wall Street finished.
US stocks closed lower
on Thursday (their time), snapping the longest winning streaks the S
P 500 and Nasdaq have had in two years.
The drop came after Treasury yields climbed as a disappointing auction of 30-year bonds, and Fed boss Jerome Powell's "not confident" comments over interest rates.
The Dow fell by 0.7% to 33,891 points, the S
P 500 lost 0.8% to 4,3747 points, and the Nasdaq lost 0.9% to 13.531.
The falls are the biggest one-day percentage drops for both the S
P and Nasdaq since October 26, and the largest for the Dow since October 27.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm chasing compensation from Optus to pay for the cost to mums Telstra service I needed to carry out my work. 200gb of data doesn't compensate me when my plan is unlimited. Optus should forfeit my next bill also... - Natty. Hey Natty, Always great to hear from you, and sorry to hear you were impacted by Wednesday's outage. A lot of Optus customers are unimpressed (to say the least) about the offer of extra data to make up for a day of no coverage, especially small business owners who couldn't operate normally. Other telcos have said Wednesday was one of their busiest days in a year, and there's plenty of anecdotal reports of people swapping providers or trying to get compensation from Optus that isn't free data. Many consumers are arguing their losses are worth much more than the compensation Optus has offered, but legally speaking, the telco might owe you nothing. So, what rights do you have, and what obligations does Optus have in return? My colleagues Leonie Thorne and consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin have put together a guide to help you understand your rights — you can read it below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Can you sue Optus or end your contract early? Here are your rights (and how to make a claim)

featuredLink.title: Can you sue Optus, or end your contract early? Here are your rights and how to make a claim

children.content: I'm chasing compensation from Optus to pay for the cost to mums Telstra service I needed to carry out my work. 200gb of data doesn't compensate me when my plan is unlimited. Optus should forfeit my next bill also...
- Natty
Hey Natty,
Always great to hear from you, and sorry to hear you were impacted by Wednesday's outage.
A lot of Optus customers are unimpressed (to say the least) about the offer of extra data to make up for a day of no coverage, especially small business owners who couldn't operate normally.

Other telcos have said Wednesday was one of their busiest days in a year, and there's plenty of anecdotal reports of people swapping providers or trying to get compensation from Optus that isn't free data.
Many consumers are arguing their losses are worth much more than the compensation Optus has offered, but legally speaking, the telco might owe you nothing.
So, what rights do you have, and what obligations does Optus have in return?
My colleagues
Leonie Thorne
and
consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin
have put together a guide to help you understand your rights — you can read it below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it last night, Optus has come to the table with an offer to ease its customers' frustrations affected by Wednesday's nationwide outage — but it's pushing back on pressure to financially compensate those left in the dark. Instead of stumping up with cash, the embattled telco giant is offering free data to appease its customers, with boss Kelly Bayer Rosmarin saying the data offer acknowledges "patience and loyalty" and is more valuable than refunding a day's service on their bills. But that's not pleased everyone, as senior business correspondent Peter Ryan explains:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 🎧 Optus outage victims want compensation, but the telco is giving them extra data

children.content: If you missed it last night,
Optus
has come to the table with an offer to ease its customers' frustrations affected by Wednesday's nationwide outage — but it's
pushing back on pressure to financially compensate
those left in the dark.
Instead of stumping up with cash, the embattled telco giant is
offering free data to appease its customers
, with boss
Kelly Bayer Rosmarin
saying the data offer acknowledges "patience and loyalty" and is
more valuable than refunding a day's service
on their bills
But that's not pleased everyone, as
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan
explains:
